liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US Federal Trade Commission has taken aim at online retail giant Amazon, accusing them of signing up millions of customers to their paid Amazon Prime subscription service without their consent, then making it hard for them to cancel. The FTC has sued Amazon in a federal court in Seattle, with documents alleging the company "knowingly duped millions of consumers into unknowingly enrolling in Amazon Prime." It also alleges Amazon used "manipulative, coercive or deceptive user-interface designs known as 'dark patterns' to trick consumers into enrolling in automatically renewing Prime subscriptions." Amazon says the FTC's claims are "false on the facts and the law" and "we make it clear and simple for customers to both sign up for or cancel their Prime membership. If you're not aware of what Amazon Prime is, the subscription service offers fast, free shipping on millions of items, lets subscribers access its Prime Video offerings, and gives them various discounts. In the US, Prime members pay $US139 a year, and it's big business for Amazon — it drives about $US25 billion annually in revenue for the company. The filing of the lawsuit is also timely — it was announced the same day Amazon confirmed the dates of its major sales event known as Prime Day, which is happening next month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Amazon accused of signing people up to Prime subscriptions without consent

children.content: The US Federal Trade Commission has taken aim at online retail giant Amazon, accusing them of signing up millions of customers to their paid
Amazon Prime subscription service without their consent
, then making it hard for them to cancel.
The FTC has sued Amazon in a federal court in Seattle, with documents alleging the company
"knowingly duped millions of consumers into unknowingly enrolling in Amazon Prime."
It also alleges Amazon used "manipulative, coercive or deceptive user-interface designs known as 'dark patterns' to trick consumers into enrolling in automatically renewing Prime subscriptions."
Amazon says the FTC's claims are "false on the facts and the law" and "we make it clear and simple for customers to both sign up for or cancel their Prime membership.

If you're not aware of what Amazon Prime is, the subscription service offers fast, free shipping on millions of items, lets subscribers access its Prime Video offerings, and gives them various discounts.
In the US, Prime members pay
$US139 a year
, and it's big business for Amazon — it drives about
$US25 billion annually in revenue for the company
The filing of the lawsuit is also timely — it was announced the same day Amazon confirmed the dates of its major sales event known as Prime Day, which is happening next month.

props.alt: A photo of the Amazon logo on its website, shown on an internet browser.

children.content: (AAP: Joe Castro)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he will name the next RBA governor in July. Current RBA governor Philip Lowe's term expires in September, and he has said in the past he would do another term in the role if he was asked. Earlier this week, deputy governor Michele Bullock was asked if she would consider the role, to which she simply replied "no comment". Chalmers is responsible for appointing the RBA governor in his role as treasurer, and he says while they are still working through it, they are aiming to confirm the next governor before parliament returns. "I'm aiming to make an announcement in July ... that's been out intention and our timeframe all along," he said. "We've always been shooting for around the middle of the year, I hope to be able to finalize a view and announce a view in July. "But certainly before the parliament comes back."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Next RBA governor to be named in July

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he will name the
next RBA governor in July
Current RBA governor Philip Lowe's term expires in September, and he has said in the past he would do another term in the role if he was asked.
Earlier this week, deputy governor Michele Bullock was asked if she would consider the role, to which she simply replied "no comment".

Chalmers is responsible for appointing the RBA governor in his role as treasurer, and he says while they are still working through it, they are aiming to confirm the next governor before parliament returns.
"I'm aiming to make an announcement in July ... that's been out intention and our timeframe all along," he said.
"We've always been shooting for around the middle of the year, I hope to be able to finalize a view and announce a view in July.
"But certainly before the parliament comes back."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed this last night, car giant Ford is slashing 400 job s in the coming months, with the majority of those impacting workers at its factory in Geelong. It amounts to the company shedding 22% of its workforce, with workers in its product development and design roles being made redundant. Ford employs around 1,800 people in Australia, and says the changes are about efficiency. "The changes are part of Ford's global drive to improve efficiency and transform its operations to meet future needs," Ford said in a statement. The Australian Manufacturing Workers' Union (AMWU) says most of the job losses won't come into effect until September. Ford's Australian operations are the latest to undergo job cuts, with around 3,800 jobs to go across its Europe sites as it shifts towards electric vehicle manufacturing. You can read more about the developments below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: Ford has cut 400 jobs in Australia

featuredLink.title: Ford set to axe 400 jobs, with Geelong workers facing biggest cuts

It amounts to the
company shedding 22% of its workforce

Ford employs around 1,800 people in Australia, and says the changes are about efficiency.
"The changes are part of Ford's global drive to improve efficiency and transform its operations to meet future needs," Ford said in a statement.
The Australian Manufacturing Workers' Union (AMWU) says most of the job losses
won't come into effect until September
Ford's Australian operations are the latest to undergo job cuts, with around 3,800 jobs to go across its Europe sites as it shifts towards electric vehicle manufacturing.
